caseTitle: NANA KOFI ANTWI V. v KOBINA ABBEY (TEACHER) ODUPONG ABBEY &
summary: In this civil appeal before the Supreme Court of Ghana, the plaintiff, Nana Kofi Antwi V, successfully claimed declaration of title, recovery of possession, damages for trespass, and perpetual injunction over land at Ayensuako. The plaintiff proved sole purchase of the land by his predecessor, Nana Kofi Antwi I (Ofinam), from the Duakwa Stool in 1910 for £465.10, supported by Exhibit A (receipt) and Exhibit B (indenture). The defendants’ claim of joint ownership with Osimpo was rejected due to lack of documentary evidence and factual impossibility (Osimpo died in 1925, after the 1910 sale). The court affirmed the High Court’s jurisdiction, holding the case was fundamentally about land title, not chieftaincy, despite the plaintiff’s status as a chief. The plaintiff also established adverse possession under the Limitation Decree, NRCD 54. The defendants’ appeal was dismissed, with the court upholding the trial court’s verdict in favor of the plaintiff.
verdict: Appeal dismissed; trial court's decision in favor of the plaintiff upheld.
citations: In Re Osu Stool; Ako Nortei II v Nortey Owuo III [2005-2006] SCGLR 628
rationaleHighlights: Plaintiff met burden of proof for sole ownership via Exhibits A and B showing payment and sale in Ofinam's name only.
Defendants failed to produce documentary evidence for joint purchase; oral claims contradicted by timeline (Osimpo deceased before alleged sale).
Court affirmed jurisdiction despite chieftaincy elements, citing In Re Osu Stool: land dispute not a 'cause affecting chieftaincy'.
Defendants' plea of joint ownership treated as confession and avoidance, shifting burden to them to prove contribution—burden not discharged.
Adverse possession established under NRCD 54: 12-year limitation period satisfied by unchallenged possession.
Gazette and National Register extracts deemed sufficient proof of plaintiff’s valid enstoolment for standing to sue.
Trial court’s findings on title and trespass upheld; appeal dismissed.
Defendants’ unauthorized felling of 50 palm trees constituted actionable trespass.
